attributes.title: Loss Aversion in Territorial Disputes: An Empirical Test

q1.value: Loss Aversion in Territorial Disputes: An Empirical Test

q2.value: Andi Zhou | Henk Erich Goemans | Michael Weintraub

q5.value: We thank Jack Levy and Dustin Tingley

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Since Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky introduced the idea that humans treat risk differently depending on whether they consider themselves ahead in the game or behind, international relations scholars have theorized extensively how the theory—known as cumulative prospect theory—can be applied to a variety of phenomena in world politics. In the light of this sustained theoretical interest, there is surprisingly little systematic empirical evidence whether, when, and how prospect theory affects international politics or foreign policy. Without the opportunity to manipulate how a situation is framed in the minds of policymakers, citizens, and voters, researchers are ill-equipped to make robust claims about the impact of so-called framing effects in observational studies of real-world events. To systematically evaluate the potential of prospect theory in helping us understand international politics, we explore territorial conflict. We employ experimental methods to measure framing effects on citizens' preferences in the context of territorial bargaining. In particular, we field survey experiments on nationally representative samples in Chile and Argentina in which we manipulate the framing of a prompt about disputed territorial claims in Antarctica. We measure respondents' propensity to choose between either a certain gain/loss or a lottery with the same expected payoff. In doing so, we introduce two major innovations into the application of prospect theory in international relations: 1) we run an experiment in a setting of an actual territorial dispute, and 2) we introduce an opponent, an essential element in international politics but missing from canonical research of prospect theory. The evidence generated by this experiment can shed light not only on the psychological microfoundations of territorial contestation but also on broader questions of bargaining and international conflict.

q16.value: First, we expect framing manipulations to generate preference reversals in territorial dispute scenarios. Framing the prompt in terms of gains will generate more risk-averse responses, while framing the prompt in loss terms will generate more risk-tolerant responses. Second, we expect the salience and identity of the opponent to affect responses in two ways: first, by steepening the utility curves of respondents and thus eliciting more extreme contrasts in gain- and loss-frame responses; and second, by shifting the reference point and making responses more risk-tolerant overall. We anticipate that these effects will be stronger with opponents that are perceived to be more hostile. Finally, we expect to see heterogeneous treatment effects across several dispositional and demographic attributes: social trust, international trust, social dominance orientation, authoritarianism, gender, and partisan ideology.

q17.value: We administer a survey experiment in Chile and in Argentina, both on nationally representative samples of approximately 3,000 respondents. Chile and Argentina are ideal places to administer this survey because of their competing territorial claims in Antarctica. Because so many disputed territories around the world are highly politically salient, it is difficult to find a case where framing the dispute in terms of territory to be gained (rather than territory already possessed “to be lost”) is credible for the population of a disputant state. The Antarctic claims are, however, well-suited for this role. On the one hand, Antarctica's remoteness, lack of permanent population, and uneventful political history (largely owing to an international treaty that set Antarctica aside as a scientific preserve) should keep its salience low in the public consciousness of both countries. On the other hand, both Chilean and Argentine law mandate official maps to depict the Antarctic claim as part of their respective national territories, so public awareness of the issue should be broad enough that presenting the issue as a political question should be credible. Our experiment is a 2-by-3 factorial design, with gain and loss frame conditions on one dimension and three conditions on the other that vary the salience and identity of the opponent. In each of the six conditions, respondents will be presented with a brief prompt introducing the territorial dispute and then are asked to choose between two policy options: accepting a certain gain or loss, or pursuing a lottery. The treatment effect will be estimated using linear regression with interactions to test for heterogeneous treatment effects.

attributes.title: Co-brooding mediates peer influence on depression and anxiety
attributes.description:
This study aims to examine mediating processes which explain how peers influence individuals’ depression and anxiety. Peers in this project refer to fellow students of the same cohort (i.e., first-year psychology students). Peers’ levels of depression predict changes in target individuals’ levels of depression (M. H. W. Van Zalk, Kerr, Branje, Stattin, & Meeus, 2010), indicating that peers influence depression. Furthermore, peers’ levels of social anxiety predict changes in target individuals’ levels of social anxiety, indicating that peers influence social anxiety (N. Van Zalk, Van Zalk, Kerr, & Stattin, 2011). Peer influence on other types of anxiety has not been examined, however. However, relatively little is known about how peers influence depression and anxiety, that is, which causal mechanisms are responsible for this type of peer influence. Co-rumination (Rose, 2002; Rose & Asher, 1999; Rose, Carlson, & Waller, 2007) has been proposed as a mediating process that explains how peers influence each other’s depression. Co-rumination refers to jointly dwelling on and rehashing emotional problems. Several longitudinal studies have shown that co-rumination predicts increases in depression among adolescent (M. H. W. Van Zalk et al., 2010) and adult (Ames-Sikora, Donohue, & Tully, 2017) samples. More recently, co-brooding (Horn & Maercker, 2016) has been proposed as one of the most detrimental component of co-rumination: it concerns a communication patterns characterized by “repetition of negative affect which is unwanted, rigid and perceived as unpleasant” (Horn & Maercker, 2016, p. 2). However, to our knowledge, no prior study has examined how co-rumination, and specifically the co-brooding component, mediates peers’ depression effects on target individuals’ depression. Moreover, although co-brooding has also been cross-sectionally linked to different types of anxiety (Carlucci, D’Ambrosio, Innamorati, Saggino, & Balsamo, 2018), to what degree co-brooding mediates peers’ anxiety effects on target individuals’ anxiety remains unclear. The current study therefore aims to examine to what extent co-brooding mediates peers’ depression and anxiety effects on target individuals’ depression and anxiety, respectively. 

The current study focuses on mediating mechanisms that explain peer influence on depression and anxiety. For depression, peer influence refers to higher levels of peers’ depression predicting stronger increases of target individual’s depression compared to lower levels of peers’ depression. For anxiety, peer influence refers to higher levels of peers’ anxiety predicting stronger increases of target individual’s anxiety compared to lower levels of peers’ anxiety. Specifically, we will examine to what extent co-brooding mediates peer influence. Co-brooding refers to repeated and consistent rehashing and dwelling on emotional problems. For depression, the predictor is the average of peers’ depression, the mediator changes in co-brooding between targets and peers, and the outcome changes in targets’ depression. For anxiety, the predictor is the average of peers’ anxiety, the mediator changes in co-brooding between targets and peers, and the outcome changes in targets’ anxiety. We will examine two types of anxiety: generalized anxiety and social phobia.

q2.value:
We have 9 directional hypotheses:

Depression:
Hypothesis 1a: We hypothesized that peers’ depression predicts changes in targets’ depression.
Hypothesis 1b: We hypothesized that peers’ depression predicts changes in targets’ co-brooding with peers.
Hypothesis 1c: We hypothesized that co-brooding with peers predicts changes in targets’ depression when controlling for peers’ depression effects on changes in targets’ depression.

If all three hypotheses 1a-1c are supported, support will be found for co-brooding mediating peer influence effects on depression. 

Generalized anxiety:
Hypothesis 2a: We hypothesized that peers’ generalized anxiety predicts changes in targets’ generalized anxiety.
Hypothesis 2b: We hypothesized that peers’ generalized anxiety predicts changes in targets’ co-brooding with peers.
Hypothesis 2c: We hypothesized that co-brooding with peers predicts changes in targets’ generalized anxiety when controlling for peers’ generalized anxiety effects on changes in targets’ generalized anxiety.

If all three hypotheses 2a-2c are supported, support will be found for co-brooding mediating peer influence effects on generalized anxiety. 

Social phobia:
Hypothesis 2a: We hypothesized that peers’ social phobia predicts changes in targets’ social phobia.
Hypothesis 2b: We hypothesized that peers’ social phobia predicts changes in targets’ co-brooding with peers.
Hypothesis 2c: We hypothesized that co-brooding with peers predicts changes in targets’ social phobia when controlling for peers’ social phobia effects on changes in targets’ social phobia.

If all three hypotheses 3a-3c are supported, support will be found for co-brooding mediating peer influence effects on social phobia.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Our study is a social network panel study, where targets and their peers all take part in an online survey on four waves with a four-week interval. 

We use a longitudinal network design (see the uploaded document called “Measurement”). We will use a panel network design, where all second semester Psychology students at Osnabrück University (n = 103) will be invited to participate on four waves with a four-week interval. 

We will use a round-robin design, where each participant will be asked to indicate what their relationship is with each of the other participants. Since they may not know who all the other participants are, we present a list of first and last names of all 103 (possible) participants. We then ask “Do you know who this is?”. Subsequent questions are only shown for those persons for whom the participant indicated “yes” (i.e., they know who this is). 

We consider any person with a “yes” as a “peer” (i.e., other Psychology students of the same cohort who they recognize by first and last name). However, we plan to explore differences between these peer relationships and friendships, since we ask in a follow-up question what their relationship is to the persons they know (e.g., friend, good friend, and best friend will be counted as “friends”).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Invitations for this study will be sent out shortly after this pre-registration (from the 22th of April 2020 onward) and participation can start immediately. All second semester students of Psychology at Osnabrück University will be invited. Participants will receive 25 EUR when they complete all four waves and 4 course credits. Questionnaires will be filled out online in Unipark on all four waves with a four-week interval

q11.value: We will invite n = 103 second semester Psychology students of the University of Osnabrück. We may invite more students if they are part of the same cohort.

q12.value: We aim to have a full network (i.e., all members of one specific network); therefore, we invite all first years registered at the Psychology program of the University of Osnabrück in the academic year 2019/2020. Since a few students may have not been registered at the time the invites were send out, we will allow these students to join by sending us an email with the request of joining our study.

q13.value: We will only allow students to participate if they belong to the cohort of first years registered at the Psychology program of the University of Osnabrück in the academic year 2019/2020.

question.value:
We have included the following measured variables (all German versions):

- Depression (PHQ-9; 9 items)
- Generalized Anxiety (GAD7; 7 items)
- The short form of the Social Phobia (Social Phobia Scale; 6 items)
- Co-brooding (3 items)
- Knowing ("Do you know who this is?" then first and last names of all 103 students are shown, with answer options "yes", "no", and "This is me". 
- Relationship type (asked for all 103 fellow students; ranging from "far acquaintance", "acquaintance", "friend", "good friend", "best friend", "family member", "romantic partner", "other")

After the project is finished, we will upload a detailed codebook, which includes a list variables.

We will calculate the mean for all items for the following scales:
1. Depression
2. Generalized anxiety
3. Social phobia 
4. Co-brooding

We will use Stochastic Actor-Oriented models in RSiena (Ripley, Snijders, Boda, Voros, & Preciado, 2018) to analyze the longitudinal panel network data (four waves with four-week interval). We will examine twelve models: two for depression; and four for anxiety; for each of these six models, one for peers (i.e., fellow students they know) and one for friends (i.e., fellow students nominated as friends).

Depression model:
-	To examine Hypothesis 1a, we will estimate peers’ depression effects on changes in targets’ depression. (Model 1)
-	To examine Hypothesis 1b, we will estimate peers’ depression effects on changes in co-brooding. (Model 2)
-	To examine Hypothesis 1c, we will estimate co-brooding effects on changes in targets’ depression, controlling for peers’ depression effects on targets’ changes in depression. (Model 2; will be examined in the same model as Hypothesis 1b)

Generalized anxiety model: 
-	To examine Hypothesis 2a, we will estimate peers’ generalized anxiety effects on changes in targets’ generalized anxiety. (Model 3)
-	To examine Hypothesis 2b, we will estimate peers’ generalized anxiety effects on changes in co-brooding. (Model 4)
-	To examine Hypothesis 2c, we will estimate co-brooding effects on changes in targets’ generalized anxiety, controlling for peers’ generalized anxiety effects on targets’ changes in generalized anxiety. (Model 4; will be examined in the same model as Hypothesis 2b)


Social phobia model: 
-	To examine Hypothesis 3a, we will estimate peers’ social phobia effects on changes in targets’ social phobia. (Model 5)
-	To examine Hypothesis 3b, we will estimate peers’ social phobia effects on changes in co-brooding. (Model 6)
-	To examine Hypothesis 3c, we will estimate co-brooding effects on changes in targets’ social phobia, controlling for peers’ social phobia effects on targets’ changes in social phobia. (Model 6; will be examined in the same model as Hypothesis 3b)

q18.value: All variables (i.e., depression, generalized anxiety, social phobia, co-rumination) will be categorised prior to analysis in RSIena (Ripley, et al. 2018). We will recode the data so that the new variables correlate with at least r > .90 with the original scales.

q19.value: We will use one-sided tests and p-values of 0.05.

q20.value:
- Participants who have no scores on depression, generalized anxiety, social phobia or co-brooding at any point in time will be excluded from the main analyses. 
- Participants who have not answered "yes" to the question "I know who this is" for any of the first and last names will be excluded from the main analyses.

q21.value: We will use the carry-forward option in RSiena.

q22.value: Co-brooding is a relatively new scale; we will therefore use a randomized split of the sample to examine an Exploratory Factor Analysis and a Confirmatory Factor Analysis in Mplus. We will first examine an Exploratory Factor Analysis on one half of the sample. Subsequently, we will use the next half of the sample to examine a Confirmatory Factor Analysis with one latent factor.

q23.value:
Ames-Sikora, A. M., Donohue, M. R., & Tully, E. C. (2017). Nonlinear Associations Between Co-Rumination and Both Social Support and Depression Symptoms. The Journal of Psychology, 151, 597–612. doi:10.1080/00223980.2017.1372345
	
Carlucci, L., D’Ambrosio, I., Innamorati, M., Saggino, A., & Balsamo, M. (2018). Co-rumination, anxiety, and maladaptive cognitive schemas: when friendship can hurt. Psychology Research and Behavior Management, 11, 133–144. doi:10.2147/PRBM.S144907
	
Horn, A. B., & Maercker, A. (2016). Intra- and interpersonal emotion regulation and adjustment symptoms in couples: The role of co-brooding and co-reappraisal. BMC Psychology, 4, 1-11. doi:10.1186/s40359-016-0159-7
	
Ripley, R. M., Snijders, T. A. B., Boda, Z., Voros, A., & Preciado, P. (2018). Manual for SIENA version 4.0 (version November 1, 2018). Oxford, UK: University of Oxford, Department of Statistics; Nuffield College.
	
Rose, A. J. (2002). Co-rumination in the friendship of girls and boys. Child Development, 73, 1830-1843. 
	
Rose, A. J., & Asher, S. R. (1999). Children's goals and strategies in response to conflicts within a friendship. Developmental Psychology, 35, 69-79. 
	
Rose, A. J., Carlson, W., & Waller, E. M. (2007). Prospective associations of co-rumination with friendship and emotional adjustment: considering the socioemotional trade-offs of co-rumination. Developmental Psychology, 43, 1019-1031. 
	
Van Zalk, M. H. W., Kerr, M., Branje, S. J. T., Stattin, H., & Meeus, W. H. J. (2010). Peer contagion and adolescent depression: The role of failure anticipation. Journal of Clinical Child & Adolescent Psychology, 39, 837-848. doi:10.1080/15374416.2010.517164
	
Van Zalk, N., Van Zalk, M. H. W., Kerr, M., & Stattin, H. (2011). Social Anxiety as Basis for Friendship Selection and Socialization in a Youth Social Network. Journal of Personality, 29, 499-525. doi:10.1111/j.1467-6494.2011.00682.x

registration_responses.q2:
We have 9 directional hypotheses:

Depression:
Hypothesis 1a: We hypothesized that peers’ depression predicts changes in targets’ depression.
Hypothesis 1b: We hypothesized that peers’ depression predicts changes in targets’ co-brooding with peers.

If all three hypotheses 1a-1c are supported, support will be found for co-brooding mediating peer influence effects on depression. 

Generalized anxiety:
Hypothesis 2a: We hypothesized that peers’ generalized anxiety predicts changes in targets’ generalized anxiety.
Hypothesis 2b: We hypothesized that peers’ generalized anxiety predicts changes in targets’ co-brooding with peers.
Hypothesis 2c: We hypothesized that co-brooding with peers predicts changes in targets’ generalized anxiety when controlling for peers’ generalized anxiety effects on changes in targets’ generalized anxiety.

If all three hypotheses 2a-2c are supported, support will be found for co-brooding mediating peer influence effects on generalized anxiety. 

Social phobia:
Hypothesis 2a: We hypothesized that peers’ social phobia predicts changes in targets’ social phobia.
Hypothesis 2b: We hypothesized that peers’ social phobia predicts changes in targets’ co-brooding with peers.
Hypothesis 2c: We hypothesized that co-brooding with peers predicts changes in targets’ social phobia when controlling for peers’ social phobia effects on changes in targets’ social phobia.

If all three hypotheses 3a-3c are supported, support will be found for co-brooding mediating peer influence effects on social phobia.

attributes.title: CommInfo4800 - Belonging
attributes.description: The purpose of this research is to study the willingness of college students to connect to others in their community.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We include a battery of questions for exploratory purposes including demographic information, school information, and personality information.

sample.value: We will have the survey open until we have used up our budget of $500. We anticipate this to result in around 270 people.

analyses.value:
We will first analyze our data using a difference in means estimator. We will do a t-test for this. We will also complete a linear regression to examine several possible covariates. These anticipated covariates are prior willingness to interact with someone they don’t know, where the participant lies on introversion/extraversion and the participant’s sense of belongingness at their university. Using these covariates, we anticipate that we will be able to increase the precision of our effect estimate. We will also do a Cohen’s D estimate to measure effect size.

We will also perform moderation analysis to determine how our intervention may be moderated by a few other variables, such as participant’s gender, # of siblings, type of program, school size, housing situation (on or off campus), and off-campus employment status.

outliers.value: Observations will be excluded if they do not completely fill out the willingness 1, intervention/control, and willingness 2 sections.

dependent.value: We will measure participant’s willingness to engage with a person that they don’t know on a college campus using a scale of 1 to 5. 1 is not willing at all and 5 is very willing.

conditions.value: We have two treatments: control and intervention. Each participant will be assigned to one treatment (between-subjects design) either control or intervention.

hypothesis.value:
Will retrospection of past positive experiences with strangers increase one’s openness to actively interact with people one does not know?
Hypothesis: People will be more willing to engage with people they do not know if they are prompted to describe a positive prior experience interacting with someone they don’t know.

study_type_other.value: Experimental survey for a class assignment

attributes.title: Replication of Study 3 from Cichocka, Marchlewska & Golec de Zavala (2016)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Replikation der Studie 3 aus: Cichocka, A., Marchlewska, M., & Golec de Zavala, A. (2016). Does Self-Love or Self-Hate predict Conspiracy Beliefs? Narcissism, Self-Esteem, and the Endorsement of Conspiracy Theories.

other.value:
Individueller Narzissmus (individual narcissism), sowie Selbstwertgefühl (self-esteem) sind Prädiktoren.

Individueller Narzissmus wird durch die deutsche Langversion von Schütz et al. (2004) des „Narcissistic Personality Inventory“ (Raskin & Terry, 1988) gemessen. Diese besteht aus 40 Itempaare.

Selbstwertgefühl wird durch die deutschsprachige Version (Collani & Herzberg, 2003) der 5-stufigen „Rosenberg’s (1965) self-esteem scale“ erfasst. Diese besteht aus 10 Items und die Skala reicht von 1 = Stimme gar nicht zu bis 5 = Stimme völlig zu.

Individueller Narzissmus und Selbstwertgefühl werden als gegenseitige Suppressoren angenommen.

Zusätzlich wird die generelle Negativität gegenüber Menschen (general negativity towards humans) als Mediator erhoben.

Die generelle Negativität gegenüber Menschen wird über eine eigene deutschsprachige Übersetzung der „humanity esteem scale“ (Luke & Maio, 2009) erfasst. Die übersetzte Skala besteht aus 10 Items und 7 Stufen von 1 = Stimme gar nicht zu bis 7 = Stimme völlig zu. Bei der Übersetzung wurde versucht die Items analog zur deutschsprachigen Version der Rosenberg-Skala (Collani & Herzberg, 2003) zu verfassen.

Item 1: Ich halte die menschliche Spezies für sehr wertvoll, jedenfalls für nicht weniger wertvoll als andere Spezies im Universum.

Item 2: Ich glaube, dass Menschen eine Reihe von sehr guten Eigenschaften besitzen.

Item 3: Alles in Allem würde ich die menschliche Spezies als Versagen ansehen.

Item 4: Menschen sind in der Lage genauso erfolgreich zu sein wie jede andere Spezies im Universum.

Item 5: Ich fürchte, es gibt nicht viel, worauf Menschen stolz sein können.

Item 6: Ich habe eine positive Einstellung zur Menschheit gefunden.

Item 7: Alles in Allem bin ich mit der Entwicklung der Menschheit zufrieden.

Item 8: Ich wünschte, ich könnte mehr Respekt für die Menschheit im Allgemeinen haben.

Item 9: Menschen sind von Zeit zu Zeit nutzlos.

Item 10: Manchmal denke ich, dass Menschen überhaupt nichts taugen.

Das Konstrukt „humanity esteem“ der „humanity esteem scale“ ist invertiert zum Konstrukt generelle Negativität gegenüber Menschen. Je höher der „humanity esteem“ umso niedriger ist generelle Negativität gegenüber Menschen bzw. umso höher ist die generelle Positivität gegenüber Menschen.

Um evtl. stichprobenspezifische Ausprägungen kontrollieren zu können werden zusätzlich einige soziodemographische Variablen (Alter, Geschlecht, kultureller & ethnischer Hintergrund, Nationalität, und Bildungsabschluss) erhoben.

Da einzelne Items der „conspiracy belief scale“ (Douglas et al., 2016) sehr USA-spezifisch sind, wird zusätzlich das Konstrukt Verschwörungsüberzeugungen durch die deutsche Version der „conspiracy mentality scale“ (Imhoff & Bruder, 2014) erfasst. Diese besteht aus 12 7-stufigen Items von 1 = überhaupt nicht bis 7 = sehr.

Die Reihenfolge der einzelnen Skalen gliedert sich in 2 Blöcke. Im Block 1 werden die Skalen zu Selbstwertgefühl und Narzissmus präsentiert. Block 2 besteht aus den Skalen für Verschwörungsüberzeugungen und die generelle Negativität gegenüber Menschen. Die Reihenfolge der Skalen innerhalb der Blöcke ist randomisiert. Die Reihenfolge der einzelnen Items innerhalb der Skalen ist ebenfalls randomisiert.

sample.value: Unsere bevorzugte Stichprobengröße, um die Haupthypothese (H2) zu testen, sollte auf Grundlage einer a priori Monte Carlo Poweranalyse für indirekte Effekte (Model: One Mediator; Objective: Set Power, vary N; Target Power; .80; Minimum N: 100; Maximum N: 500; Sample Size Steps: 1; Number of Replications: 5000; Monte Carlo Draws per Rep: 20000; Random Seed: 1234; Confidence Level: 95; Input Method: Standardized Coefficients; X=Selbstwertgefühl; M=Narzissmus; Y=Verschwörungsüberzeugungen; a=.28; b=.35;c‘=-.09; Schoemann et al., 2017) mindestens 122 Teilnehmer (111 Personen + 10%) groß sein.

analyses.value:
Zum Testen der Hypothesen wird das allgemeine lineare Modell angenommen.

Zur Überprüfung der Hypothese 1a wird eine lineare Regressionsanalyse durchgeführt. Verschwörungsüberzeugungen als Kriteriumsvariable und individueller Narzissmus als Prädiktor.

Zur Überprüfung der Hypothese 1b wird zunächst eine lineare Regressionsanalyse durchgeführt. Verschwörungsüberzeugungen als Kriteriumsvariable und Selbstwertgefühl als Prädiktor. Anschließend wird eine multiple Regressionsanalyse durchgeführt, mit Verschwörungsüberzeugungen als Kriteriumsvariable und individueller Narzissmus und Selbstwertgefühl als Prädiktoren.

Hypothese H2 wird durch die multiple Regressionsanalyse der Hypothese 1b überprüft. Zur Bestimmung der Signifikanz des Suppresionseffekt wird anschließend ein Sobel-Test, sollten die Voraussetzung zur Anwendung erfüllt sein, und Bootstrapping des Regressionsmodells durchgeführt.

Hypothese H3 wird analog zur H2 getestet. Zusätzlich zum Modell von H1b/H2 wird zusätzlich die Mediatorvariable „humanity esteem“ hinzugefügt. Das anschließende Vorgehen ist analog zur H2.

outliers.value: Analog zur den Kriterien der Originalstudie werden nur Teilnehmer in die Analyse aufgenommen, die in Deutschland leben, und deren Datensätze vollständig sind.

dependent.value:
Die Kriteriumsvariable ist Verschwörungsüberzeugungen (conspiracy belief).

Diese wird erfasst durch eine eigene deutsche Übersetzung der „conspiracy belief scale“ (Douglas et al. 2016). Die Übersetzung besteht aus 7 Items auf einer 7-stufigen Skala von 1 = Stimme gar nicht zu bis 7 = Stimme völlig zu.

Item 1: Wissenschaftler betreiben Panikmache bezüglich des Klimawandels, weil es ihren eigenen Interessen dient.

Item 2: Es gab einen offiziellen Auftrag des MI6 Prinzessin Diana zu ermorden, genehmigt durch Teile des Establishments.

Item 3: Das AIDS Virus wurde in einem Labor geschaffen.

Item 4: Der Angriff auf das World Trade Center war kein Terroranschlag, sondern eine Regierungsverschwörung.

Item 5: Die amerikanischen Mondlandungen wurden vorgetäuscht.

Item 6: Regierungen halten Beweise für die Existenz von Außerirdischen zurück.

Item 7: Lee Harvey Oswald arbeitete mit der CIA zusammen, um Präsident John F. Kennedy zu ermorden.

hypothesis.value:
Die Zielsetzung dieser Arbeit ist die direkte Replikation der Studie 3 aus Cichocka et al. (2016) und dessen Forschungsergebnisse.

Der Untersuchungsschwerpunkt ist die Rolle eines besonders hohen bzw. niedrigen Selbstwertgefühl (high or low self-esteem) in der Vorhersage von Verschwörungsüberzeugungen (conspiracy belief).

Individueller Narzissmus (individual narcissism) ist mit einem übermäßig hohen Selbstwertgefühl verbunden. Ein niedriges Selbstwertgefühl geht mit einer generellen Negativität gegenüber Menschen (general negativity towards humans) einher. Die empirische Differenzierung zwischen individuellen Narzissmus und hohem Selbstwertgefühl (high self-esteem), sowie zwischen einer generellen Negativität gegenüber Menschen und niedrigem Selbstwertgefühl (low self-esteem), sind daher von weiterem Erkenntnisinteresse.

Folgende Hypothesen sollen in der Studie überprüft werden:

H1a: Individueller Narzissmus ist ein signifikant positiver Prädiktor von Verschwörungsüberzeugungen.

H1b: Selbstwertgefühl ist ein signifikant negativer Prädiktor von Verschwörungsüberzeugungen, wenn die „Überlappung“ von individuellen Narzissmus und Selbstwertgefühl kontrolliert wird.

H2: Die beiden Prädiktoren, individueller Narzissmus und Selbstwertgefühl, wirken signifikant vermindernd (supprimierend) auf den Zusammenhang des jeweils anderen Prädiktors mit Verschwörungsüberzeugungen (Suppressor Effekt).

H3: Der signifikant negative Zusammenhang von Selbstwertgefühl mit Verschwörungsüberzeugungen wird neben individuellen Narzissmus zusätzlich durch generelle Negativität gegenüber Menschen mediiert. Es wird eine serielle Mediation und eine vollständige Mediation von generellen Negativität gegenüber Menschen angenommen.

Hypothese 2 ist die zentrale Hypothese dieser Arbeit.

attributes.title: GOTV Field Experiment on MSU first-year students: In-class voter interventions

q1.value: GOTV Field Experiment on MSU first-year students: In-class voter interventions

q2.value: Kjerstin Thorson | Daniel E. Bergan | Dustin Carnahan | Nazita Lajevardi | Mel Medeiros | Sarah Reckhow

q15.value: This study is designed to affect political behavior by increasing voter turnout among the incoming first-year class of MSU students. We will also track the impact of those interventions on a diverse array of civic outcomes through a pre- and post-election survey. Previous research has found that many get-out-the-vote (GOTV) interventions are ineffective. One of the more promising areas, however, is when someone comes into the classroom to teach students about the voting process. We believe that students who are taught about the voting process in a short presentation in their first-year college writing class will be more likely to turn out to vote than those who do not receive such an intervention. Additionally, prior studies have shown that social pressure interventions can increase voter turnout—for example, by encouraging subjects to make a pledge to vote or making the intention to vote a social activity that is visible to other people. Thus, we also believe that student who receive a presentation about voting plus an opportunity to make a pledge to vote will be more likely to turn out to vote. In addition, we believe there will be spillover and peer effects in which the roommates of students who received the information about voting will also turnout to vote at higher rates. We also hope to learn what types of messages about voting (the process, issues to vote on, or efficacy) are most effective at stimulating voter turnout. First-year writing courses will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: a control group receiving no treatment, an informational treatment group where students hear a short presentation about how to vote with information about how to register to vote and information about the major issues at play in Michigan campaigns, or a social pressure treatment group where students receive the same information as the informational group, plus a magnet where students can pledge that they will vote as well as information about how talking with their roommates about elections can have important effects. From late September – October before Michigan's voter registration deadline, all first- year students will be sent a pretest survey. From late September to mid-October, student volunteers will come to first-year writing classes that were assigned to either of the treatment groups and lead a short presentation with a Powerpoint to talk through the logistics of and reasons for voting. After the November 2018 election, we will once again contact all first year students and send them a posttest survey. We will also contract with Catalist to receive a list of the students who turned out to vote, which we will match to students’ WRA class enrollment and compare to the different treatment conditions.

q16.value: (1) Those students in the two treatment groups will turn out to vote at higher rates than those in the control group. (2) Those students in the social pressure group will turn out to vote at a higher rate than the control group (3) Those students in the social pressure group will turn out to vote at a higher rate than the informational treatment group. (4) The on-campus roommates of those in the control group will turn out at lower rates than the roommates of those in the social pressure treatment group. (5) The on-campus roommates of those in the informational treatment group will turn out at lower rates than the roommates of those in the social pressure treatment group. (6) Roommates of all treated students will turn out more. (7) The female on campus roommates of those females in the treatment groups will turn out at higher rates than those on campus roommates of males in the treatment groups. (8) The female on campus roommates of those females in the treatment groups will turn out at higher rates than those on campus roommates of everyone else in the experiment.

q17.value: After the election, we will do three things. First, we will once again contact all first-year students and send them an opt-in posttest survey. Second, the registrar’s office will give us information on each student’s roommate. We will also obtain the contact information for first-year students enrolled in a WRA first-year writing class from the Registrar. Catalist, a company that securely and confidentially validates voter turnout across the country for universities and political campaigns, will use students' names and addresses to validate their voter turnout. Catalist will provide us with a list of who turned out to vote which we will match to students' WRA class enrollment and compare to the different treatment conditions. Finally, first-year students in one of the WRA writing classes will be invited to take an online survey with questions about demographics, political interest, affiliation and efficacy, news use, social media use, socialization of politics, anxiety about politics, and identity. Students' voter turnout records, experimental condition, and pre- and post-election surveys will be linked but anonymized. Our analysis will isolate intent-to-treat effects and also non- intent-to-treat effects to account for non-adherence to assigned treatment.

q19.value: 146 first year writing classes. 48 in control (no classroom intervention), 49 in treatment 1 (basic intervention), and 49 in treatment 2 (social pressure intervention)

registration_responses.q1: GOTV Field Experiment on MSU first-year students: In-class voter interventions
registration_responses.q2: Kjerstin Thorson | Daniel E. Bergan | Dustin Carnahan | Nazita Lajevardi | Mel Medeiros | Sarah Reckhow
registration_responses.q15: This study is designed to affect political behavior by increasing voter turnout among the incoming first-year class of MSU students. We will also track the impact of those interventions on a diverse array of civic outcomes through a pre- and post-election survey. Previous research has found that many get-out-the-vote (GOTV) interventions are ineffective. One of the more promising areas, however, is when someone comes into the classroom to teach students about the voting process. We believe that students who are taught about the voting process in a short presentation in their first-year college writing class will be more likely to turn out to vote than those who do not receive such an intervention. Additionally, prior studies have shown that social pressure interventions can increase voter turnout—for example, by encouraging subjects to make a pledge to vote or making the intention to vote a social activity that is visible to other people. Thus, we also believe that student who receive a presentation about voting plus an opportunity to make a pledge to vote will be more likely to turn out to vote. In addition, we believe there will be spillover and peer effects in which the roommates of students who received the information about voting will also turnout to vote at higher rates. We also hope to learn what types of messages about voting (the process, issues to vote on, or efficacy) are most effective at stimulating voter turnout. First-year writing courses will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: a control group receiving no treatment, an informational treatment group where students hear a short presentation about how to vote with information about how to register to vote and information about the major issues at play in Michigan campaigns, or a social pressure treatment group where students receive the same information as the informational group, plus a magnet where students can pledge that they will vote as well as information about how talking with their roommates about elections can have important effects. From late September – October before Michigan's voter registration deadline, all first- year students will be sent a pretest survey. From late September to mid-October, student volunteers will come to first-year writing classes that were assigned to either of the treatment groups and lead a short presentation with a Powerpoint to talk through the logistics of and reasons for voting. After the November 2018 election, we will once again contact all first year students and send them a posttest survey. We will also contract with Catalist to receive a list of the students who turned out to vote, which we will match to students’ WRA class enrollment and compare to the different treatment conditions.
registration_responses.q16: (1) Those students in the two treatment groups will turn out to vote at higher rates than those in the control group. (2) Those students in the social pressure group will turn out to vote at a higher rate than the control group (3) Those students in the social pressure group will turn out to vote at a higher rate than the informational treatment group. (4) The on-campus roommates of those in the control group will turn out at lower rates than the roommates of those in the social pressure treatment group. (5) The on-campus roommates of those in the informational treatment group will turn out at lower rates than the roommates of those in the social pressure treatment group. (6) Roommates of all treated students will turn out more. (7) The female on campus roommates of those females in the treatment groups will turn out at higher rates than those on campus roommates of males in the treatment groups. (8) The female on campus roommates of those females in the treatment groups will turn out at higher rates than those on campus roommates of everyone else in the experiment.
registration_responses.q17: After the election, we will do three things. First, we will once again contact all first-year students and send them an opt-in posttest survey. Second, the registrar’s office will give us information on each student’s roommate. We will also obtain the contact information for first-year students enrolled in a WRA first-year writing class from the Registrar. Catalist, a company that securely and confidentially validates voter turnout across the country for universities and political campaigns, will use students' names and addresses to validate their voter turnout. Catalist will provide us with a list of who turned out to vote which we will match to students' WRA class enrollment and compare to the different treatment conditions. Finally, first-year students in one of the WRA writing classes will be invited to take an online survey with questions about demographics, political interest, affiliation and efficacy, news use, social media use, socialization of politics, anxiety about politics, and identity. Students' voter turnout records, experimental condition, and pre- and post-election surveys will be linked but anonymized. Our analysis will isolate intent-to-treat effects and also non- intent-to-treat effects to account for non-adherence to assigned treatment.
registration_responses.q19: 146 first year writing classes. 48 in control (no classroom intervention), 49 in treatment 1 (basic intervention), and 49 in treatment 2 (social pressure intervention)
